Staffing Your DevOps Organization: Agile Development and the Division of Labor

The extreme division of labor prevailing during much of the 20th century was a transitory phenomenon.
DevOps patterns and practices represent a different way of working, and that is based on the different demands of the 21st century.
  • DevOps represents a reincarnation of "craft work."
  • A reincarnation, because it is craft work with a new layer of automation available.
What is the role of the "DevOps toolchain" in establishing this new way of working??
  • The mechanical, repetitive tasks the assembly-line worker performed in the 20th century must be automated!
How can an enterprise balance the need for highly capable specialists with the DevOps demand to "break down silos"?
  • An agile enterprise needs to hire people with broad understanding of various technologies and how they fit into the enterprise and forward its goals.
  • Nevertheless, we still are coping with extremely complex technologies, and we will need people who understand them in great depth!
There is no "one size fits all" approach to implementing a DevOps change.
  • Each enterprise will have to make its own trade-offs between its need for specialists and its need for generalists.
  • To suggest this trade-off could be made according to some mechanical formula would be... "anti-DevOps"!
